9.33 Coreena Ford That's it - and what's to come 
This morning I’m writing about plans for another bar and restaurant in Newcastle city centre, as well as an interview with Mark Hird, founder of Tavistock Hospitality and Sonnet 43 brew house. 
Also, Ange Upex, commercial editor is also posting some articles from our Let’s Work Together campaign. 
That’s the end of the blog for this week. . . Robert Gibson’s in the hot seat from Monday. . .tra! 9.27 Coreena Ford 
Here’s a proper link to that story on investment at Slaley Hall. 
As visitors know, Slaley Hall has 141 bedrooms, a health club and spa and two championship golf courses. The hotel also offers outdoor activities centre which include 4x4 driving, clay pigeon shooting, segwaying (SEGWAYING? - we’re there - Ed) and paint balling. 9.22 Coreena Ford Mars makes £23m investment 
Food giant Mars is to invest £23 million in a manufacturing plant, creating new jobs and boosting production. 
The money will be invested in the King’s Lynn site in Norfolk, where a new production line will be opened next year to meet demand for Uncle Ben’s Ready to Heat rice. 
Michael Ryan, regional president of Mars Food, Western Europe & Russia, said: “We have been manufacturing from this site for over 50 years and continue our commitment to investing and growing the site which manufactures some of the UK’s favourite family brands.” 
Environment Secretary Elizabeth Truss, MP for South West Norfolk opened new office facilities at the site, which employs almost 300 workers. The new investment will create 28 jobs Ian Waldie/Getty Images 9.16 Coreena Ford £1m investment at Slaley Hall 
Q Hotels has announced a £1m investment into one of its North East sites in a bid to make it the region’s best resort hotel. 
The hotel group has refurbished large parts of Slaley Hall, near Hexham in Northumberland, and strengthened its management after taking it over from the De Vere group in 2014. 
Money has been spent on room refurbishment, air conditioning and heating, and improving access to the Edwardian mansion, which is set in over 1,000 acres of rolling countryside. Slaley Hall 9.15 Coreena Ford The pound at 9am. . . 
The pound at 9am was 1.2950 dollars compared to 1.2925 dollars at the previous close. The euro at 9am was 0.8557 pounds compared to 0.8561 pounds at the previous close 9.06 Coreena Ford Reaction to The View opening 
This has pretty much been the reaction to The View... 9.00 Coreena Ford Most read on Journal Business - Tynemouth Longsands' new restaurant 
This is the most popular story today, by a country mile. . .news of the founders of Crusoe’s in Tynemouth’s expansion. 
It’s been public knowledge that a new beachfront business was opening at the north end of the beautiful Longsands beach for almost two years. . .so we’ve all been a bit excited to find out it finally opens on Tuesday, July 12 . And HOW good does it look?! It’s not called The View for nothing. 
Well done Wilson family -get ready for big queues, (you had me at Prosecco on tap). The View cafe bar restaurant is about to open at Longsands in Tynemouth 8.55 Coreena Ford Reaction to the Convergys expansion news 
The US firm’s expansion news is going down particularly well 8.50 Coreena Ford Major coup for Newcastle as Convergys create 600 new jobs 
And this is the one I couldn’t fully reveal details of yesterday morning..! 
The news that Convergys is taking over the whole of The Rocket, the brand spanking-new Grade A office building at Stephenson Quarter provides us with a massive boost, not least of all because the firm is almost doubling its North East workforce from 700 to 1,300. Brilliant news all round. Sally Ann Norman The Rocket at Stephenson Quarter Development in Newcastle, which will soon house hundreds of Convergys workers 8.45 Coreena Ford North East LEP calls on Government to ensure EU funding 
Our top story this morning is on how the body charged with developing the North East economy is seeking assurances from the Government over the delivery of EU funding to the region. 
The North East Local Enterprise Partnership (LEP) has committed £89.5m of EU structural funding to boost growth in the region, while a further £104.5m was submitted to the Government for approval in the run up to last month’s referendum. 
The projects already approved will support more than 7,400 businesses across the North East LEP area, and also provide support and training to around 30,000 people either looking for work or trying to progress through improving their skills. 
Read the full story by business editor Graeme Whitfield here . Andrew Hodgson of SMD Ltd in Wallsend 8.37 Coreena Ford Regional breakdown on the consumer confidence report 
There’s a semi-regional breakdown for the consumer confidence report - and there are distinct differences in how confidence has changed regionally, with the North being the least confident. 
Confidence dropped 19 points in the north of England and 11 points in Scotland. 
In the south, including London, there has been a two point drop. 
Confidence among 16 to 29-year-olds has dropped 13 points, but this group remains the most optimistic of all age groups. 
The biggest dip in confidence from a household income perspective is among those earning between £25,000 and £49,999, who registered a 16 point drop. Meanwhile, figures released by BDO’s monthly High Street Sales Tracker (HSST) show the Brexit vote had an immediate impact on the high street, which suffered its worst June in more than 10 years. 
A strong start to June saw overall sales grow 3.8% year-on-year in the first week, but the ‘Brexit effect’ hit retailers with increasing severity as the month wore on. 
Sales saw a 3.1% drop in the second week and by the final week of June - two days after the Brexit vote - overall year-on-year sales had plummeted 8.1%. 8.32 Coreena Ford Consumer confidence drops to lowest level in two decades 
It’s been an emerging theme for the last couple of week, and now a report has shown consumer confidence has seen its sharpest drop in more than 20 years since the Brexit vote. 
A third of shoppers believe prices will increase rapidly in the next year and some 60% of consumers expect the general economic situation to worsen in the next 12 months. 
That’s up from 46% in June, while just 20% expect it to improve, down from 27% last month, a one-off GfK Consumer Confidence Barometer survey taken after the referendum found. 
The proportion of people who believe prices will increase rapidly in the next 12 months has jumped 20 percentage points from 13% to 33%. 
The core index has fallen eight points to minus 9, and all key measures used to calculate it have fallen. 
The long-running survey, which dates back to 1974, has not seen a sharper drop since December 1994. 
GfK head of market dynamics Joe Staton said: 
During this period of uncertainty we’ve seen a very significant drop in confidence, as is clear from the fact that every one of our key measures has fallen, with the biggest decrease occurring in the outlook for the general economic situation in the next 12 months. 8.25 Coreena Ford John Lewis warns of Sterling plunge impact 
Yet another high street retailer has warned of issues ahead presented by the falling pound. 
The boss of John Lewis has warned that the plunge in sterling could become a problem for the department store chain. 
Andy Street said that although the firm is “fully hedged” against currency fluctuations for 2016/17, next year it could be an issue. 
He said: “The big issue is the decline in exchange rates. 
We hedged this year but the issue is next year, it will have an effect. If inflation gets into value chain, it will feed through.” 
Since the referendum result, sterling has collapsed against both the dollar and the euro. 
Earlier this week, John Lewis saw sales growth slow in the seven days following Britain’s decision to leave the European Union. 
But Mr Street denied it was anything to do with Brexit, saying it was more likely linked to an earlier start to its summer clearance sale and the weather. “The market has been challenging even before Brexit. Since the result, there’s been no implication for sales,” Mr Street said. 
However, Mr Street did say that his major concern is the potential reduction in the growth of consumer spending as the economy looks set to fall into recession. 
“For us to start being concerned, the obvious thing for us is a reduction in the growth in consumer spending. 
But has it actually changed behaviour? It’s just far too soon to say.” Managing director (MD) Andy Street of John Lewis 8.20 Coreena Ford Indeed....Brexit bounce expected for all publishers 
Newspaper groups across the board have seen a spike in sales following the political and economic turmoil unleashed as a result of the Brexit vote. 
Ian Whittaker, analyst at Liberum, said: 
The past months have been tough for the UK newspapers as they have suffered from the UK ad spend volatility ahead of the Brexit vote. 
Yet, the Brexit vote should be positive for newspapers: in the short term, it should help boost circulation revenues given the coverage given to the Brexit vote and its consequences; and in the medium to long term, the Brexit vote - where most newspapers supported a Leave vote - will be taken as a demonstration of how much influence newspapers still have, which is a persuasive argument to use with advertisers. 8.17 Coreena Ford i newspaper sales boom following Brexit 
Publisher Johnston Press has been given a Brexit bounce, with sales of its i newspaper soaring following Britain’s decision to quit the European Union. 
Sales data from last week shows daily circulation consistently over 300,000, peaking at 319,000. 
Johnston Press acquired the i in April, when its average audited circulation was 270,182. 
The firm also said that advertising revenue for the same week was the highest since the acquisition. 
The company said: 
These figures show a further increase from the week of the referendum, indicating a continued desire for impartial and informative journalism, highlighting the vital role that newspapers play around major milestones for the country. 
Notwithstanding the referendum, which has evidently been beneficial for newspaper groups in general, i’s circulation and readership. 
The online version of the newspaper, launched in April, also saw a record amount of traffic, breaking through the one million page views per week barrier for the first time. 8.12 Coreena Ford FTSE 100 and Sterling latest 
The FTSE-100 index opened at 6533.79. 
And a marginally improving pound at 8am was 1.2930 dollars compared to 1.2925 dollars at the previous close. The euro at 8am was 0.8568 pounds compared to 0.8561 pounds at the previous close. 8.10 Coreena Ford Tata Steel - speciality steel sale set for confirmation 
It’s later today that the sale of the speciality steel business is expected to be announced, after a meeting of Tata’s board in Mumba. 
Business Secretary Sajid Javid will meet senior Tata board members in Mumbai today during a visit to India to discuss future trade links following the UK vote to leave the EU. 
He said: 
Following the referendum result, my absolute priority is making sure the UK has the tools it needs to continue to compete on the global stage. 
That is why I am in India today to launch these initial trade discussions. 
There is a strong bilateral trade relationship between our two countries and I am determined that we build on this. 
Over the coming months, I will be conducting similar meetings with other key trade partners, outlining the government’s vision for what the UK’s future trade relationship might look like. Business Secretary Sajid Javid 8.05 Coreena Ford Tata Steel latest as unions press for clarity 
Indian steel giant Tata is being urged not to allow its biggest UK plant to “wither on the vine” as speculation mounts that the company is to announce the sale of part of its assets. 
The firm looks set to confirm that it will sell its speciality steel business, which employs 2,000 workers in Hartlepool, Rotherham and Stocksbridge. 
The move would increase uncertainty among workers in the rest of Tata’s operations, including the country’s biggest steel plant at Port Talbot in South Wales. 
Tata has been assessing several bids for weeks after announcing earlier this year that it was selling its loss-making UK business. 
Speculation has been growing that it will sell off its speciality steel business but will continue to assess options for the rest of its plants. 
Unite warned Tata against “walking away” from Port Talbot in a few years’ time after leaving it to “wither on the vine”. 
National officer Harish Patel said: 
The cloud of uncertainty over steelworkers’ heads needs to be lifted by Tata giving binding commitments about its long-term intentions regarding Port Talbot and its UK strips business. 
If Tata is to retain the goodwill of the workforce then its board needs to give guarantees over Port Talbot and assurances that it won’t conduct a fire sale of its speciality and tubes business. 
Port Talbot and the UK strips business can have a viable and profitable long-term future with the right investment. 
They have a world-class workforce making world-beating products. 
Unite will be pressing Tata for clarity over its intentions and ensuring it sticks to its promise to be a responsible seller and act ethically. Peter Byrne/PA Wire
